Connections that require a disclosure could be based instead on things like friendship, family, or employment relationships, or deals between acquaintances.

sections.title: My Facebook page identifies my employer. Should I include an additional disclosure when I post on Facebook about how useful one of our products is?
sections.text: Yes. People reading your posts in their news feed â€“ or on your profile page â€“ might not know where you work or what products your employer makes. In addition, many businesses are so diversified that readers might not realize that the products youâ€™re talking about are sold by your company.

sections.title: A famous athlete has millions of followers on Twitter and is well known as a spokesperson for a particular product. Does the athlete have to disclose being paid in every tweet about the product?
sections.text:
It depends on what readers of the tweets would understand. If a significant minority of viewers doesnâ€™t know about the relationship and would care if they did, the relationship should be disclosed. Determining whether the audience for a tweet is aware of and cares about a relationship can be tricky, so we recommend disclosure.
Also, if a disclosure is needed in one post for a brand, itâ€™s probably needed in all posts, because you canâ€™t assume that viewers will see multiple posts.

sections.title: A celebrity has millions of followers on Instagram. Many people know that the celebrity regularly charges advertisers to mention their products in posts. Does the celebrity have to disclose being paid for a particular post about a product?
sections.text: It depends on the extent to which people reading the celebrityâ€™s posts understand that a particular post is a paid endorsement. Many followers may know generally about the celebrityâ€™s connections to advertisers, but, for any one post, if a significant minority of readers donâ€™t know it was paid, a disclosure may be needed. Again, determining what readers know can be tricky, so we recommend disclosure.

sections.title: Iâ€™m a video blogger who lives in London. I create sponsored videos on YouTube for products that are also sold in the U.S. Do I need to tell my viewers that Iâ€™ve been paid to endorse the products even though I donâ€™t live in the U.S.?
sections.text: If itâ€™s reasonably foreseeable that your YouTube videos will be seen by and impact U.S. consumers, U.S. law would apply and you would need a disclosure. Also, the U.K. and many other countries have similar laws and policies relating to endorsements. So, youâ€™ll want to check those, too.

sections.title: An influencer creates their own brand and sells their product through their social media accounts and website. Do they need to disclose anything?
sections.text: If it is obvious from an influencerâ€™s endorsement that that the brand is the influencerâ€™s own, no disclosure is necessary. If itâ€™s not clear or sometimes not clear that itâ€™s the influencerâ€™s brand, that fact should be disclosed.

sections.title: What does the FTC have to say about product placements on television shows?
sections.text:
Federal Communications Commission law (FCC, not FTC) requires TV stations to include disclosures of product placement in TV shows.
The FTC has expressed the opinion that, under the FTC Act, product placement (that is, merely showing products or brands in third-party entertainment content, as distinguished from sponsored content or disguised commercials) doesnâ€™t require a disclosure that the advertiser paid for the placement.

sections.title: What if a pair of TV talk show hosts express an opinion on their show about a video game they were paid to promote? The segment is humorous and the hosts arenâ€™t video game experts. Is that a product placement and does the payment have to be disclosed?
sections.text: By expressing a positive opinion about the product â€“ even if the segment just shows them playing the game against each other and reacting positively â€“ the hosts are making endorsements, which is more than a mere product placement. If the audience doesnâ€™t know the hosts are getting paid and if that information would affect the weight or credibility the audience gives the endorsement, it should be disclosed. It doesnâ€™t matter that the segment is humorous or that the hosts arenâ€™t experts. However, in some cases, a host may say something about a product that is obviously an advertisement, in which case a disclosure probably isnâ€™t necessary. For example, think of an old-time TV show where the host goes to a different set, holds up a cup of coffee, says â€œWake up with EFG Coffee. Itâ€™s how I start my day!â€ and takes a sip.

sections.title: What if a talk show has a â€œbargains segmentâ€ where the showâ€™s producers have partnered with a brand or brands to recommend certain discount products to viewers? Is that just a product placement? Does there need to be a disclosure?
sections.text: That isnâ€™t just a product placement as the show is recommending certain products. So there should be disclosures of the paid relationship with the marketer(s). To be most effective, the disclosures should be presented at the beginning of the segment and when specific products are endorsed. The disclosures should be straightforward in explaining the financial connection and shouldnâ€™t use unclear expressions like â€œweâ€™ve partnered with vendors.â€

sections.title: Many social media platforms allow you to share your interests with friends and followers by clicking a button or sharing a link to show that youâ€™re a fan of a particular business, product, website or service. Is that an "endorsement" that needs a disclosure?
sections.text: Many people enjoy sharing their fondness for a particular product or service with their social networks. If you write about how much you like something you bought on your own and you have no relationship with the advertiser, no disclosure is necessary. However, if youâ€™re doing it as part of a sponsored campaign or youâ€™re being compensated â€“ for example, getting a discount on a future purchase or being entered into a sweepstakes for a significant prize â€“ a disclosure is appropriate.

sections.title: Iâ€™m an avid social media user who often gets rewards for participating in online campaigns on behalf of brands. Is it OK for me to click a â€œlikeâ€ button, pin a picture, or share a link to show that Iâ€™m a fan of a particular business, product, website or service as part of a paid campaign?
sections.text:
Pinning a picture or sharing a link to endorse a companyâ€™s products or services as part of a sponsored brand campaign probably requires a disclosure.
We realize that some platform features â€“ like Facebookâ€™s â€œlikeâ€ buttons â€“ donâ€™t allow you to make a disclosure. Advertisers shouldnâ€™t encourage endorsements using features that donâ€™t allow for clear and conspicuous disclosures. Whether the FTC would say a disclosure is needed may depend on the overall impression of the endorsement â€“ for example, whether consumers would consider â€œlikesâ€ to be material in their decision to patronize a business or buy a product.
However, an advertiser buying fake â€œlikesâ€ is very different from an advertiser offering incentives for â€œlikesâ€ from actual consumers. If â€œlikesâ€ are from non-existent people or people who have no experience using the product or service, they are clearly deceptive, and both the purchaser and the seller of the fake â€œlikesâ€ could face enforcement action.

sections.title: I posted a review of a service on a website. Now the marketer has taken my review and changed it in a way I think is misleading. Am I liable for that? What can I do?
sections.text: No. You arenâ€™t liable for the changes the marketer made to your review. You could, and probably should, complain to the marketer and ask it to stop using your altered review. You also could report it to the FTC , your local consumer protection organization, and the Better Business Bureau.

sections.title: Is tagging a brand in a social media post a sufficient disclosure that I have a connection to a brand?
sections.text: No. Tagging a brand is an endorsement, but itâ€™s not a disclosure that you have a connection to a brand. You could just be tagging it because you like it.

sections.title: Is there special wording I have to use to make the disclosure?
sections.text: No. The point is to give readers the essential information in words that are easy to understand. The best disclosures are simple, like â€œThis is an ad for BRANDâ€ or â€œThis video is paid for by BRANDâ€ or â€œBRAND paid me to tell you about it.â€

sections.title: Do I have to hire a lawyer to help me write a disclosure?
sections.text: No. What matters is effective communication. A disclosure like â€œCompany X gave me [name of product] to try, and I think itâ€™s greatâ€ gives your readers the information they need. Or, at the start of a short video, you might say, â€œThe products Iâ€™m going to use in this video were given to me by their manufacturers.â€ That gives the necessary heads-up to your viewers (assuming you werenâ€™t also paid by the manufacturers, in addition to getting the products for free, in which case you should disclose that you were paid).

sections.title: In this document, you provide examples of various disclosures you think will or are likely to be effective. Are you saying those disclosures will work for children and teens?
sections.text: No. As the Endorsement Guides suggest, children and teens can react differently from adults. A disclosure that works with adults might not work with younger individuals. Indeed, research suggests that disclosures will not work for younger children. Accordingly, advertisers and endorsers should be particularly careful in their use of endorsements directed to this audience.

sections.title: Do I need to list the details of everything I get from a company for reviewing a product?
sections.text: No. What matters is whether the information would have an effect on the weight readers would give your review. So, whether you got $100 or $1,000, you could simply say you were â€œpaid.â€ (That wouldnâ€™t be good enough, however, if youâ€™re an employee or co-owner.) And if what you got is so small that it wouldnâ€™t affect the weight readers would give your review, you may not need to disclose anything.

sections.title: How do I know if what I got is so small that it wouldnâ€™t affect the weight readers would give my endorsement?
sections.text: There is no easy answer to that question and there is no threshold amount that would apply in all situations. It might vary by the endorser and by the type of product being endorsed.

sections.title: Do I always need to disclose when I got a product for free, and do I need to say any more than that?
sections.text:
It depends on the product and on what else, if anything, you got from the company. Saying only that you got a product for free suggests you didnâ€™t get anything else.
For example, if an app developer gave you their 99-cent app for free for you to review it, that information might not have much effect on the weight that readers give to your review. But if the app developer also gave you $100, knowledge of that payment would have a much greater effect on that weight. So a disclosure that simply said you got the app for free wouldnâ€™t be good enough, but, as discussed above, you donâ€™t have to disclose exactly how much you were paid.
Similarly, if a company gave you a $50 gift card to give away to one of your readers and a second $50 gift card to keep for yourself, it wouldnâ€™t be good enough only to say that the company gave you a gift card to give away.

sections.title: Iâ€™m doing a review of a video game that hasnâ€™t been released yet. The manufacturer sent me the game and is paying me to review it. Is it enough just to disclose that the manufacturer gave me a â€œsneak peekâ€ of the game?
sections.text: No. Merely referring to your early access doesnâ€™t tell people that you were paid for your review. You should say that you were paid. If you werenâ€™t paid but the manufacturer just let you keep the game for free, it might be deceptive to refer to what you were given as merely a â€œsneak peek.â€

sections.title: Would a single disclosure on my home page that â€œmany products discussed on this site are provided free by their manufacturersâ€ be enough?
sections.text: No. A single disclosure on your home page wonâ€™t be sufficient because people visiting your site might read individual reviews or watch individual videos without seeing the disclosure on your home page. Even if some viewers read the disclosure, it doesnâ€™t tell them which products were and werenâ€™t provided for free by their manufacturers.

sections.title: If I upload a video to TikTok and that video requires a disclosure, can I put the disclosure in the text description of the video?
sections.text: The text description on TikTok is in small print, it doesnâ€™t stand out, and it often doesnâ€™t contrast against the background of the video. Also, TikTok videos often have many competing elements. A disclosure in the text description is thus very unlikely to be clear and conspicuous. When content creators want viewers to read something, they superimpose much larger text over their videos.

sections.title: Can I just superimpose a larger text disclosure over my video?
sections.text: It depends how you make the endorsement in the video. As the Endorsement Guides say, if the endorsement is made through visual means, the disclosure should be made at least visually. If the representation is made audibly, the disclosure should be made at least audibly. And if the representation is made through both visual and audible means, the disclosure should be made both visually and audibly. A disclosure presented simultaneously in both the visual and audible portions of an ad is more likely to be clear and conspicuous.

sections.title: If I upload a video to YouTube and that video requires a disclosure, can I put the disclosure in the description that accompanies the video?
sections.text: You can, but thatâ€™s not enough on its own because consumers can easily miss disclosures in the video description. Many people might watch the video without even seeing the description page, and even those who do see that page might not see or read the disclosure. The disclosure has the best chance of being clear and conspicuous if itâ€™s included in the video itself. ( See the Q&A above about how a disclosure should be made in a video. )

sections.title: What about having a disclosure in the description of an Instagram post? Is that good enough?
sections.text:
When people view Instagram streams, longer descriptions are truncated, with only the first two or three lines displayed. To see the rest, you have to click â€œmore.â€ If an Instagram post makes an endorsement in the beginning of the description, any required disclosure should be presented without having to click â€œmore.â€
If the picture on an Instagram post conveys an endorsement without the viewer having to read the accompanying description and a significant minority of viewers donâ€™t read the description, a disclosure in the description could be inadequate. You might need a disclosure superimposed over the picture. Also, if an Instagram post makes an endorsement in a video, there should be a disclosure in the video, preferably both visually and audibly. (See the discussion in â€œ So, can I just superimpose a larger text disclosure over my video? â€)

sections.title: Would a button on a web page that says DISCLOSURE or LEGAL or something like that be enough, so long as the button links to a full disclosure?
sections.text: No. A hyperlinked disclosure like that is easily avoidable, meaning that the disclosure is not clear and conspicuous. Many consumers wonâ€™t click on it and will miss the disclosure. Usually, your disclosure can be brief and there is no space-related reason to use a hyperlink to provide access to it.

sections.title: If a brand (for example, a tourism organization) is sponsoring a trip for an influencer, does every single post the influencer posts while in that destination need to include a disclosure like #ad?
sections.text:
An influencer canâ€™t assume that followers will read more than one of their posts and associate them with each other. As we say in .com Disclosures, How to Make Effective Disclosures in Digital Advertising , â€œUse disclosures in each ad.â€ If a disclosure is required in an ad, â€œthe disclosure should be in each and every ad that would require a disclosure if that ad were viewed in isolation.â€
That said, itâ€™s possible that some posts made while the influencer is at that destination might not mention or promote the destination. If a post is non-promotional, e.g., a close up of the influencerâ€™s child without tags or other clues as to the location, there is no need for a disclosure. Simply tagging a post made while in that destination as an #ad might be fine, but it could be confusing in some circumstances. When the sponsorâ€™s identity is unclear but would matter to consumers, the sponsor should probably be identified.

sections.title: The social media platform I use has a built-in feature that allows me to disclose paid endorsements. Can I just rely on that tool?
sections.text:
Not necessarily. Itâ€™s good that some platforms offer these tools, and we donâ€™t want to dissuade you from using them. But just because a platform offers this feature is no guarantee that itâ€™s an effective way for influencers to disclose their material connection to a brand.
In an investigation, the FTC would evaluate whether the use of the tool by itself clearly and conspicuously discloses the relevant connection. Indeed, for any disclosure on social media, whether or not through the use of a platform tool, the FTC would consider several key factors in determining whether the disclosure is clear and conspicuous.
One factor is placement. The disclosure should catch usersâ€™ attention and be placed where they arenâ€™t likely to miss it. A key consideration here is how users view posts on a particular platform. For example, on a photo platform, users paging through their streams will likely look at the eye-catching images. Therefore, a disclosure placed above a photo may not attract their attention. Similarly, a disclosure in the lower corner of a video could be too easy for users to overlook.
A second factor is readability. The disclosure should use a simple-to-read font with a contrasting background that makes it stand out.
A third factor is clarity. The disclosure should be a worded in a way thatâ€™s clear, unambiguous, and understandable to the ordinary reader. For example, simply flagging that a video â€œcontains paid contentâ€ might not be sufficient if the video mentions multiple products or services without identifying which content is paid.
The big-picture point is that the ultimate responsibility for clearly and conspicuously disclosing a material connection rests with the influencer and the brand â€“ not the platform. To be on the safe side, itâ€™s always best to add your own disclosure even if a platform offers its own disclosure tool.
It would be highly beneficial if all social media platforms developed standardized, built-in disclosure tools that are easy for endorsers to use and easy for viewers to notice and understand, and if the platforms also tested the effectiveness of such disclosures. FTC staff is always willing to discuss that with any platforms that might want to make improvements.

sections.title: How can I make a disclosure on Snapchat or in Instagram Stories?
sections.text: You can superimpose a disclosure on Snapchat or Instagram Stories, just as you can superimpose any other words over the images on those platforms. The disclosure should be easy to notice and read in the time your followers have to look at the image. Consider how much time you give your followers to look at the image, how much competing text there is to read, how large the disclosure is, and how well it contrasts against the image. (You might need to have a solid background behind the disclosure.) If your post includes video, see the discussion in â€œ So, can I just superimpose a larger text disclosure over my video? â€ Also note that, if you just include an audio disclosure, users who watch videos without sound wonâ€™t hear it.

sections.title: What about a platform like Twitter or Facebook?
sections.text: The FTC doesnâ€™t mandate the specific wording of disclosures. Regardless of the advertising medium or platform, the same general principle applies: people should get the information they need to evaluate sponsored statements. Starting a post with â€œAd:â€ or â€œPaid adâ€ or â€œ#adâ€ or â€œAdvertising:â€ or â€œAdvertisementâ€ would likely be effective. The words â€œSponsoredâ€ and â€œPromotionâ€ at the beginning of a post might also be effective, but â€œSponsored by XYZâ€ or â€œPromotion by XYZâ€ would be clearer (where â€œXYZâ€ is a brand name). Also see the discussion in â€œ So, can I just superimpose a larger text disclosure over my video? â€

sections.title: Iâ€™ve been paid to make an endorsement in a Facebook post. Can I disclose the relationship in the comments section?
sections.text: No. A disclosure in the comments to a post is easily avoidable and thus not clear and conspicuous.

sections.title: You just talked about putting short disclosures at the beginning of a social media post. What about â€œ#adâ€ at or near the end of a post?
sections.text: Weâ€™re not necessarily saying that, if you use a disclosure like â€œ#ad,â€ you have to put it at the beginning of a post. The FTC doesnâ€™t dictate where you have to place the disclosure. The issue for us is whether the disclosure is easily noticeable, easily understandable, and hard to miss by ordinary consumer. A disclosure in the middle or at the end of a post is easier to miss and thus less likely to be effective. Thatâ€™s particularly true if itâ€™s at the end of a long post or mixed in with links or other hashtags.

sections.title: Does #ad work both for a paid post as well as for the receipt of a free product?
sections.text: Yes, it does.

sections.title: Is there anything special about hashtags in a post? Is â€œ#adâ€ better than â€œAd:â€ or â€œadâ€?
sections.text: There is nothing special about hashtags from a disclosure perspective. â€œ#ad,â€ â€œAd:,â€ and â€œadâ€ at the beginning of a post are probably all equal.

sections.title: What if we combine our company name, â€œCool Stylle,â€ with â€œad,â€ as in â€œ#coolstylleadâ€?
sections.text: There is a good chance that consumers wonâ€™t notice and understand the significance of the word â€œadâ€ at the end of a hashtag, especially one made up of several words combined like â€œ#coolstyllead.â€ Disclosures need to be easily noticed and understood.

sections.title: Is â€œ#paidforbyXYZâ€ (when XYZ is a brand name) an acceptable disclosure?
sections.text: It might work, but itâ€™s possible that consumers would find it hard to read or understand when the words all run together. â€œPaid post by [brand]â€ or â€œPaid post for [brand]â€ would be much clearer and only takes up a few more characters.

sections.title: Is it good enough if an endorser says â€œthank youâ€ to the sponsoring company?
sections.text: No. A â€œthank youâ€ to a company or a brand doesnâ€™t necessarily communicate that the endorser got something for free or that they were given something in exchange for an endorsement. The endorser could just be thanking a company or brand for providing a great product or service. But â€œThanks XYZ for the free productâ€ or â€œThanks XYZ for the gift of ABC productâ€ would be good enough â€“ if thatâ€™s all you got from XYZ. If thatâ€™s too many characters for the format, thereâ€™s always â€œAd.â€

sections.title: What if I call my endorsement an â€œ#endorsementâ€? Is that clear enough?
sections.text: No. Thatâ€™s because using the word â€œendorsementâ€ doesnâ€™t make clear to people that youâ€™re talking about the special way that word is used in the Endorsement Guides. In other words, it doesnâ€™t inform people that you were paid or incentivized to make your endorsement or that you have any other connection to the brand.

sections.title: What about saying, â€œXYZ Company asked me to try their productâ€?
sections.text: That disclosure might be sufficient if the context of the endorsement makes clear that the endorser got to keep the product for free after trying it, and if the endorser didnâ€™t get anything else. It wouldnâ€™t be sufficient if those things arenâ€™t clear or if the company gave money or something else to the endorser.

sections.title: I provide marketing consulting and advice to my clients. Sometimes I also promote my clientâ€™s products in my personal social media accounts. Are â€œ#client,â€ â€œ#advisor,â€ and â€œ#consultantâ€ all acceptable disclosures?
sections.text:
Probably not. Those one-word hashtags are ambiguous and likely confusing. It would be much clearer to say something like, â€œIâ€™m a paid consultant to the marketers of XYZâ€ or â€œI work with XYZ brandâ€ (where XYZ is a brand name).
Of course, on some platforms you might need a shorter disclosure, and itâ€™s possible that a shorter message might be effective. For example, something like â€œXYZ_Consultantâ€ or â€œXYZ_Advisorâ€ might be clear enough.

sections.title: Would â€œ#ambassadorâ€ or â€œpartnerâ€ work in a tweet? What about or â€œ#XYZ_Ambassadorâ€ or â€œ#XYZ_Partnerâ€?
sections.text: The use of â€œ#ambassadorâ€ or â€œpartnerâ€ is ambiguous and confusing. â€œ#XYZ_Ambassadorâ€ or â€œ#XYZ_Partnerâ€ will likely be more understandable (where XYZ is a brand name).

sections.title: Is â€œGiftedâ€ a sufficiently clear disclosure?
sections.text: No. The word â€œGifted,â€ by itself without a brand reference, is likely to be ambiguous. However, â€œGifted by XYZâ€ (when XYZ is a brand name) should be sufficient when all youâ€™ve received is a free product.

sections.title: I post regularly about the night life in my city and a club gave me free tickets to one of its events so I would post about it. Is it good enough if I disclose that â€œI received free ticketsâ€?
sections.text:
No. Your followers could think you received the free tickets from a relative, a friend, or a radio giveaway, rather than from the club itself, so that disclosure is inadequate. You should say who gave you the tickets. You could instead disclose that the tickets â€œwere complimentaryâ€ or â€œon the house.â€
For similar reasons, a disclosure like â€œI was given [name of product] for freeâ€ wonâ€™t be effective because it doesnâ€™t tell people who gave you the product. Thatâ€™s why we donâ€™t recommend use of the hashtag â€œ#freeproduct.â€ But â€œI was given a free [name of product] to review,â€ should probably be clear enough.

sections.title: Iâ€™m a blogger, and XYZ Resort Company is flying me to one of its destinations and putting me up for a few nights. If I write an article sharing my thoughts about the resort destination, how should I disclose the free travel?
sections.text: Your disclosure could be just, â€œXYZ Resort paid for my tripâ€ or â€œThanks to XYZ Resort for the free trip.â€ It would also be accurate to describe your blog as â€œsponsored by XYZ Resort.â€

sections.title: Where in my blog should I disclose that my review is sponsored by a marketer? Does it matter if the disclosure is at the top or at the bottom?
sections.text: Yes, it matters. A disclosure should be placed where it easily catches consumersâ€™ attention and is difficult to miss. Readers might overlook a disclosure at the very top of the page, outside of the blog. Their eyes will probably be drawn to a picture or a headline, and they will then probably read down. Consumers may miss a disclosure at the bottom of a blog or page. Many wonâ€™t read to the very end or look after the end of the blog itself. A disclosure is more likely to be seen if itâ€™s very close to, or â€“ even better â€“ part of, the endorsement to which it relates.

sections.title: Iâ€™ve been paid to endorse a product on social media. My posts, videos, and tweets will be in Spanish. In what language should I disclose that Iâ€™ve been paid for the promotion?
sections.text: The connection between an endorser and a marketer should be disclosed in whatever language or languages the endorsement is made, so your disclosures should be in Spanish.

sections.title: Iâ€™ve been paid for a video review that Iâ€™m uploading to YouTube. When in the review should I make the disclosure? Is it okay if itâ€™s at the end?
sections.text: Viewers are more likely to miss a disclosure at the end of the video, especially since some may not watch the whole thing. Having it at the beginning of the review would be better. Having multiple disclosures during the video would be even better. Of course, if your disclosure is only at the beginning, you and the brand that paid you shouldnâ€™t provide consumers with a link to your review that bypasses the beginning and skips over the disclosure. If YouTube has been enabled to run ads during your video, a disclosure that is obscured by ads isnâ€™t clear and conspicuous.

sections.title: Would your answer be different if my paid endorsement of a product is in the middle of a longer YouTube video?
sections.text: In that case, the best place for the disclosure would be right before or at the beginning of the actual endorsement.

sections.title: Iâ€™m getting paid to do a videogame playthrough and give commentary while Iâ€™m playing. The playthrough â€“ which will last several hours â€“ will be live streamed. Would a disclosure at the beginning of the stream be okay?
sections.text: Since viewers can start watching at any time, they could easily miss a disclosure at the beginning of the stream or at any other single point in the stream. If there are multiple, periodic disclosures throughout the stream, people are more likely to see them no matter when they tune in. To be on the safe side, you could have a continuous, clear and conspicuous disclosure appear throughout the entire stream. We also advise that you add a disclosure to any description of the stream before potential viewers click through to it.

sections.title: My YouTube channel is a product review channel, and I receive products for free from brands to do reviews. I tell the audience at the beginning of each video that the products being reviewed were sent to me for free. In the descriptions of my videos, I include affiliate links for viewers to buy the products (if they choose), and I make a commission from those sales. Do I need to disclose in my videos that I receive those commissions (along with the disclosure that I got the products for free), or is a disclosure next to the link good enough?
sections.text: You should disclose the affiliate relationship both in the videos and in the description near the links. (For how to make such disclosures, see the Q&A below in the section entitled â€œ What About Affiliate or Network Marketing? â€)

sections.title: I have attended sneak peek events and use #comped or #hosted. Can influencers/bloggers use #comped and #hosted for non-paid endorsements?
sections.text: Neither #comped nor #hosted is sufficiently clear. It would be fine to say, for example, â€œXYZ brand flew me to Hawaii for their launch event at the EFG Resort,â€ assuming that is all the brand did.

sections.title: Is a personalized discount code an adequate disclosure?
sections.text: When an influencer uses a clearly personalized and unique discount code for a brandâ€™s products (e.g., one matching the influencerâ€™s Instagram name with the percentage savings, such as iammike20%), that probably conveys that a relationship exists between the influencer and the brand. Whether it conveys that they have a financial relationship is less clear. If a significant minority of readers doesnâ€™t understand that the influencer gets paid when people use the personalized discount code, there should be a clearer disclosure. When itâ€™s not obvious what consumers understand, we recommend erring on the side of disclosure.

sections.title: Besides disclosing my relationship with the company whose product Iâ€™m endorsing, what are the essential things I need to know about endorsements?
sections.text:
The most important principle is that an endorsement has to represent the accurate experience and opinion of the endorser:
You canâ€™t talk about your experience with a product if you havenâ€™t tried it.
If youâ€™ve only tried a product once, you canâ€™t suggest you use it regularly.
If you thought it was terrible or mediocre, you canâ€™t say itâ€™s good or terrific.
You canâ€™t otherwise misrepresent your experience with or opinions about a product.
Also, you shouldnâ€™t make claims about a product that would require proof the advertiser doesnâ€™t have. The Guides say that an endorser who isnâ€™t an expert may be liable for misleading or unsubstantiated statements about a productâ€™s performance or effectiveness in certain circumstances. For example, the endorser could be liable when what they say or write isnâ€™t consistent with their personal experience. They also could be liable if what they say or write isnâ€™t approved by the advertiser and goes beyond the scope of their personal experience.

sections.title: Our company is a multi-level marketing company (MLM). In our business, participants directly market the MLMâ€™s products and attempt to recruit other individuals to become participants in the MLM program. Are participants liable as â€œendorsersâ€?
sections.text: Because participants are directly engaged in selling the MLM's products, the MLM's opportunity, or both, they generally would be liable as an advertiser for any misrepresentations they make. In our experience, they are also usually acting as agents of the MLM.

sections.title: My company runs contests and sweepstakes on social media. To enter, participants have to send a Tweet or make a pin with the hashtag #XYZ_Rocks. (â€œXYZâ€ is the name of my product.) Isnâ€™t that enough to notify readers that the posts were incentivized?
sections.text: No. Many readers would likely not understand a hashtag like that to mean those posts were made as part of a contest or that the posters had received something of value (in this case, a chance to win the contest prize). Making the word â€œcontestâ€ or â€œsweepstakesâ€ part of the hashtag (e,g., #XZY_Contest or #XYZ_Sweepstakes) should be enough. However, the word â€œsweepsâ€ probably isnâ€™t because itâ€™s likely that many people wouldnâ€™t understand what that means. You should also instruct participants where to make the disclosure so that itâ€™s clear and conspicuous (e.g., at the beginning of the post).

sections.title: Is #sweepstakes by itself a good enough disclosure?
sections.text: No. Letâ€™s say that JKL-Cola is having a sweepstakes and, to enter, a consumer has to make a Facebook post identifying their happiest place to drink JKL-Cola and submit a screenshot of the post. If a consumer posts, â€œMy happiest place to drink JKL-Cola is in my jacuzzi. #sweepstakes,â€ their social media friends or followers might not understand that the post was incentivized by a sweepstakes. It would be clearer if the consumer said, â€œMy happiest place to drink JKL-Cola is in my jacuzzi. #JKLCola_Sweepstakes.â€

sections.title: My company runs a retail website that includes customer reviews of the products we sell. We give out free products to a select group of our customers for them to review. We tell them to be honest, whether itâ€™s positive or negative, because we just want the reviews to be helpful. Do we still need to disclose which reviews were of products the reviewer received for free?
sections.text: Yes. Knowing that reviewers got the product for free would probably affect the weight your customers give to the reviews, even if you didnâ€™t intend for that to happen. Reviewers who are incentivized to write their reviews because they received free products or the like may tend to give more positive reviews. For example, they may believe theyâ€™ll stop getting free products if their reviews are negative, despite your assurances that you only want their honest opinions. Also, if these reviewers give ratings on a scale, such as a number of stars, and if those ratings are substantially higher than those given by customers who bought the products, it could result in a substantial increase in the overall rating. If thatâ€™s the case, consumers may be misled if they just look at the inflated overall star rating rather than reading individual reviews with disclosures. In instances like that, you should disclose next to every overall or other summary rating that it includes reviewers who were given free products.

sections.title: My company, XYZ, operates one of the most popular multi-channel networks on YouTube. We just entered into a contract with a videogame marketer to pay some of our network members to produce and upload video reviews of the marketerâ€™s games. Weâ€™re going to have these reviewers announce at the beginning of each video (before the action starts) that itâ€™s â€œsponsored by XYZâ€ and also have a prominent simultaneous disclosure on the screen saying the same thing. Is that good enough?
sections.text: Many consumers could think XYZ is a neutral third party and wonâ€™t realize from your disclosures that the review was really sponsored (and paid for) by the videogame marketer, which has a strong interest in positive reviews. If the disclosure said, â€œSponsored by [name of the video game],â€ that would be good enough. As to the placement of the disclosure, the Guides say that simultaneous written and spoken disclosures are the best, all other things being equal. Whether a particular disclosure is easy to understand or difficult to miss depends on the actual disclosure.

sections.title: My company would like to get more online reviews by sending a link to a review page to customers in specific regions where we have the highest customer satisfaction. We would not send a link to customers in areas where we know our customer experience is poor. Is that OK?
sections.text: No. Only asking for reviews from customers who you think are more likely to be happy with your product would be misleading if it substantially skews the favorability of the reviews.

sections.title: I understand from the Guides that I canâ€™t use review management software to completely suppress negative reviews. Can I use it to give my company one or two days to draft a response to negative reviews so I can post the review and our response at the same time? Can I use it to delay posting the negative reviews while I try to contact the unhappy customers and get them to change their minds?
sections.text:
If you want to delay posting reviews in order to have time to respond to them, you should delay posting all reviews, positive and negative, for the same, reasonable period of time. Treating all reviews equally in this way would not result in injury or deception. However, delaying the posting only of negative reviews, even just by a few days, could create a biased picture of a product at any given time, which makes this practice problematic.
Delaying the posting of negative reviews while you try to change customersâ€™ minds and then not posting the originally submitted reviews, would likely give a biased and misleading picture of what customers think about your products and services.

sections.title: Is there anything wrong with contacting customers who left negative reviews and trying to make them happy? If I succeed, can I ask them to change their reviews?
sections.text: Youâ€™re welcome to contact unhappy customers and respond to their concerns. You can also ask them if theyâ€™ll add updates to their reviews. However, asking them to change or delete their initial negative reviews could mislead readers.

sections.title: The Guides talk about deceptively organizing customer reviews. Can you give an example of deceptive organizing?
sections.text: Letâ€™s say you organize consumer reviews of your products so all of the 5-star reviews are first and then all 4-star reviews, 3-star reviews, 2-star reviews, and 1-star reviews are displayed in that order, regardless of the date of the review. A consumer could get a misleading picture of what users think, because itâ€™s unlikely the consumer will read through all of the reviews to get to the negative ones. This is true even if you give consumers the option to re-sort the reviews, because many consumers might not realize that the default sort is by star rating.

sections.title: My company wants to contact customers and interview them about their experiences with our service. If we like what they say about our service, can we ask them to allow us to quote them in our ads? Can we pay them for letting us use their endorsements?
sections.text:
Yes. You can ask your customers about their experiences with your product and feature their comments in your ads. If they have no reason to expect compensation or any other benefit before they give their comments, thereâ€™s no need to disclose your payments to them.
However, if youâ€™ve given these customers a reason to expect a benefit from providing their thoughts about your product, you should disclose that fact in your ads. For example, if customers are told in advance that their comments might be used in advertising, they might expect to receive a payment for a positive review, and that could influence what they say, even if you tell them you want their honest opinion. In fact, even if you tell your customers you arenâ€™t going to pay them but they might be featured in your advertising, that opportunity might be seen as having a value. So the fact that they knew this when they gave the review should be disclosed (e.g., â€œCustomers were told in advance they might be featured in an ad.â€).

sections.title: Iâ€™m starting a new online business and I don't have money for advertising, so I need publicity. Can I tell people that if they say good things about my business on a third-party review platform, Iâ€™ll give them a discount on items they buy through my website?
sections.text: No. Endorsements must reflect the honest opinions or experiences of the endorser. You canâ€™t condition an incentive â€“ for example, a discount â€“ on a review being positive, as that may motivate people to give a positive review for reasons unrelated to their honest opinion about your product. Your plan could even cause people who have never done business with you to make up positive reviews. However, assuming it doesnâ€™t violate the review platformâ€™s policy, itâ€™s okay to invite all of your customers to post honest reviews, positive or negative, after theyâ€™ve actually used your products or services. If youâ€™re offering customers something of value in return for these reviews, tell them in advance that they should disclose what they received from you and that they wonâ€™t get the discount unless they do so. (Note, however, that many platforms prohibit such incentives.) Further, if offering an incentive materially increases your average star rating over non-incentivized reviews you receive, you may still be engaging in a deceptive practice, despite the disclosures in the individual reviews.

sections.title: A company is giving me a free product to post a review on one particular social media platform. They say that, if I voluntarily review it on a different social media platform or on a website, I donâ€™t need to make any disclosures. Is that true?
sections.text: No. If you received a free or discounted product to provide a review somewhere, your connection to the company should be disclosed everywhere you endorse the product.

sections.title: If I get a free product to review, do I need a disclosure no matter how I got it?
sections.text: Yes. It doesnâ€™t matter whether the company gives you a code, ships it directly to you, gives you money to buy it yourself, or reimburses you after you buy it. The key issue is always the same: If consumers knew the company gave it to you for free (or at a substantial discount), that information could affect how much weight they give your review.

sections.title: My company wants to get positive reviews. Weâ€™re thinking about distributing product discounts through various services that encourage reviews. Some services require people who want discount codes to provide information allowing sellers to read their other reviews before deciding whether to issue the codes. Other services send out offers of a limited number of discount codes and then follow up by email to see whether the recipients have reviewed the products. Still others send offers of discount codes to those who previously posted reviews in exchange for discounted products. All of these services say that reviews are not required. Does it matter which service I choose? I would prefer that recipients of my discount codes not have to disclose that they received discounts.
sections.text: Whichever service you choose, the recipients of your discount codes need to disclose that they received a discount to encourage their reviews. Even though the services might say that a review is not â€œrequired,â€ itâ€™s at least implied that a review is expected. If these services materially inflate your productâ€™s average star rating, you might still be engaging in a deceptive practice despite the disclosures in the individual reviews.

sections.title: Our company uses a social media network to promote our products. We understand weâ€™re responsible for monitoring our network. What kind of monitoring program do we need? Will we be liable if someone in our network says something false about our product or fails to make a disclosure?
sections.text:
Advertisers need to have reasonable programs in place to train and monitor members of their network. The scope of the program depends on the risk that deceptive practices by network participants could cause consumer harm. For example, a network devoted to the sale of health products may require more supervision than a network promoting, say, a new fashion line. Here are some elements every program should include:
Given an advertiserâ€™s responsibility for substantiating objective product claims, explain to members of your network what they can (and canâ€™t) say about the products â€“ for example, a list of the health claims they can make for your products, along with instructions not to go beyond those claims;
Instruct members of the network on their responsibilities for clearly and conspicuously disclosing their connections to you, including exactly how you want them to make the disclosures;
Periodically search for what members of your network are saying; and
Take appropriate action if you find questionable practices.
Itâ€™s unrealistic to expect you to be aware of every single statement made by a member of your network. But itâ€™s up to you to make a reasonable effort to know what participants in your network are saying. That said, itâ€™s unlikely that the activity of one rogue influencer would be the basis of a law enforcement action if your company has a reasonable training, monitoring, and compliance program in place.
If your company pre-approves your influencersâ€™ paid social media posts, you should review the posts for truth-in-advertising compliance, including any disclosure responsibilities. If your company doesnâ€™t have a pre-approval process like that, consider starting one. Itâ€™s much easier to review posts before theyâ€™re posted than to search for them afterwards.

sections.title: You say to periodically search for what our endorsers are saying. How often do we need to do that? Can you give us a standard, like monitoring of X% of our influencers every week or every month?
sections.text: Thereâ€™s no one-size-fits-all standard. If regular monitoring is too much for you, you should probably switch to pre-approval of posts.

sections.title: For influencers who only get free products, is just sending them training material sufficient?
sections.text:
Itâ€™s important, but insufficient. If a company sends influencers a free unsolicited product and nothing else, it should ask them to clearly and conspicuously disclose the gift in any resulting social media posts or other endorsements, tell them how it should be disclosed, and ask them to tag the brand. The company should monitor the resulting tagged posts. We understand that software solutions exist to monitor compliance online. The FTC takes no position on their quality and recognizes that software like that might be too expensive for some companies. The extent of compliance monitoring needed, whether or not you use such software, may depend upon the types of products and possible claims involved, e.g., whether the claims involve health or safety.
Also, even if the only things youâ€™re sending influencers are unsolicited free products, youâ€™re still on the hook for their deceptive claims, so the training material should describe what they can and canâ€™t say about your products.

sections.title: How can my company be expected to monitor ephemeral or short-lived endorsements like those on Instagram Stories or Snapchat?
sections.text: There is probably no practical way to monitor those posts in real time. Thatâ€™s why you should require that paid posts arenâ€™t made without you approving them in advance.

sections.title: Our companyâ€™s social media program is run by our public relations firm. We tell them to make sure they â€“ and people they pay on our behalf â€“ comply with applicable laws and the FTCâ€™s Endorsement Guides. Is that good enough?
sections.text: Your company is ultimately responsible for what others do on your behalf. You should make sure your public relations firm has an appropriate program in place to train and monitor members of your social media network. Ask for regular reports confirming that the program is operating properly and monitor the network periodically. Delegating part of your promotional program to an outside company doesnâ€™t relieve you of responsibility under the FTC Act.

sections.title: How long after we pay someone or give them a free product should we continue to monitor them?
sections.text: We donâ€™t have a basis for setting a specific time period. The short answer is that the length of your monitoring should be reasonable and doesnâ€™t have to go on forever. If you have an endorser under contract, you certainly should monitor them during the length of the contract and for a reasonable time, such as a few months, after the contract expires. If there was no contract and you just sent a free product, it would probably be reasonable to monitor endorsers for at least a few months. But there is no set time period that makes sense for all circumstances, and depending on the facts, you may be responsible for a post even after a few months.

sections.title: We only hire influencers to post to Instagram and we have a really good monitoring program of posts on that platform. Do we have to also monitor every other social media platform for what our influencers are saying about us?
sections.text: If you donâ€™t otherwise monitor those platforms, you donâ€™t need to do so. However, if you learn that one of your influencers is saying things they shouldnâ€™t on another platform or not making adequate disclosures, donâ€™t ignore it.

sections.title: I have a small network marketing business. Advertisers pay me to distribute their products to members of my network who then try the product for free. How do the principles in the Guides affect me?
sections.text: You should tell the participants in your network that, if they endorse products they have received through your program, they should make it clear they got the products for free. Advise your clients â€“ the advertisers â€“ that if they provide free samples directly to your members, they should remind the members of the importance of disclosing the relationship when the members talk about those products. Put a program in place to check periodically whether your members are making those disclosures, and to deal with anyone who isnâ€™t complying.

sections.title: My company recruits influencers for marketers who want product endorsements. We pay and direct the influencers. What are our responsibilities?
sections.text: You could be liable if you play a role in creating or disseminating endorsements containing representations you know or should know are deceptive. You may also be liable if endorsements fail to disclose unexpected material connections, whether by disseminating advertisements without necessary disclosures or by hiring and directing endorsers who fail to make necessary disclosures. Like an advertiser, your company needs to have reasonable programs in place to train and monitor the influencers you pay and direct.

sections.title: Iâ€™m an affiliate marketer with links to an online retailer on my website. When people read what Iâ€™ve written about a particular product and then click on those links and buy something from the retailer, I earn a commission from the retailer. What do I have to disclose? Where should the disclosure be?
sections.text:
You should disclose your relationship to the retailer clearly and conspicuously on your site, so readers can decide how much weight to give your endorsement. You could say something like, â€œI get commissions for purchases made through links in this post.â€ In some instances â€“ like when the affiliate link is embedded in your product review â€“ a single disclosure may be adequate. When the review has a clear and conspicuous disclosure of your relationship and the reader can see both the review containing that disclosure and the link at the same time, readers have the information they need. But if the product review containing the disclosure and the link are separated, readers may not make the connection.
As for where to place a disclosure, the guiding principle is that it has to be clear and conspicuous. The closer the disclosure is to your recommendation, the better.

sections.title: Is â€œaffiliate linkâ€ by itself an adequate disclosure? What about a â€œbuy nowâ€ button?
sections.text: Consumers might not understand that â€œaffiliate linkâ€ means that the person placing the link is getting paid for purchases made through the link. Similarly, a â€œbuy nowâ€ button would not be adequate.

sections.title: Is â€œpaid linkâ€ by itself an adequate disclosure?
sections.text: â€œPaid linkâ€ right next to an affiliate link should be an adequate disclosure of the nature of the link.

sections.title: Is â€œcommissionable linkâ€ a good disclosure for an affiliate link?
sections.text: No. â€œCommissionable linkâ€ is probably not a clear disclosure.

sections.title: What if Iâ€™m including links to product marketers or to retailers as a convenience to my readers, but Iâ€™m not getting paid for them?
sections.text: Then there isnâ€™t any connection you need to disclose.

sections.title: Does this guidance about affiliate links apply to links in my product reviews that appear on someone elseâ€™s website or in my tweets?
sections.text: Yes. The same guidance applies anytime you endorse a product and get paid through affiliate links.

sections.title: Itâ€™s clear that whatâ€™s on my website is a paid advertisement, not my own endorsement or a review of the product. Do I still have to disclose that I get a commission if people click through my website to buy the product?
sections.text: If itâ€™s clear that whatâ€™s on your site is a paid advertisement, you donâ€™t have to make additional disclosures. Just remember that whatâ€™s clear to you may not be clear to everyone visiting your site, and the FTC evaluates ads from the perspective of reasonable consumers.

sections.title: My website publishes our own, independent product reviews. I also sell ad space on my website. Some marketers want to buy ad space for their products next to our reviews of those products. What do I need to do?
sections.text: If itâ€™s obvious what are paid ads and if a marketerâ€™s buying ad space from you doesnâ€™t impact what products you review, what you say about them, or the placement or prominence of those reviews, thereâ€™s nothing you need to do. Your readers would not be misled because your only connection to the marketers is that you sell it ad space.

sections.title: Iâ€™m a product manufacturer and our website provides links to all authorized sellers. Some of our authorized sellers pay us referral fees. Do we need to disclose the affiliate fees?
sections.text: If you provide links on your website to all authorized vendors of your products and donâ€™t provide any benefits or preferences to the ones that pay affiliate fees, you donâ€™t need to make any disclosures.

sections.title: One of our companyâ€™s paid spokespersons is an expert who appears on news and talk shows promoting our products. They also recommend our products in their social media posts. Should the expert disclose their connection when promoting our products?
sections.text: Yes. Your expert spokespersons should disclose their connections when promoting your products outside of traditional advertising media (in other words, on programming that consumers wonâ€™t recognize as paid advertising). That includes talk show appearances by an expert on your payroll. The same guidance also would apply to comments by the expert in their social media posts.

sections.title: I work for a terrific company. Can I mention our products to people in my social networks? My â€œfriendsâ€ and followers wonâ€™t be misled since itâ€™s clear in my online profiles where I work. How about on a review site?
sections.text:
Whether you can mention your companyâ€™s products on social media posts may depend on your companyâ€™s policies. If your employer allows you to do that and you decide to mention your companyâ€™s products on social media posts, you should disclose your relationship to the company. Put yourself in the readerâ€™s shoes. Isnâ€™t the employment relationship something you would want to know before relying on someone elseâ€™s endorsement? Listing your employer on your profile page isnâ€™t enough. After all, people who just read what you post wonâ€™t get that information. Even those who read your profile page might not associate your employer with the products you endorse.
If you write a review of one of your companyâ€™s products on a website that features consumer reviews, people reading the review probably wonâ€™t know who you are or where you work. You definitely should disclose your employment relationship when writing such a review. You should also make sure you comply with your companyâ€™s social media policy.

sections.title: On their own initiative and without us asking, several of our employees used their personal social network accounts to â€œshareâ€ one of our companyâ€™s posts. Do they need to disclose that they work for our company?
sections.text: Whether there should be any disclosure depends upon whether the â€œsharesâ€ could be viewed as promoting one of your companyâ€™s products or services. If so, employees endorsing the post should disclose their relationship to the company. Thatâ€™s fairly easy to do â€“ for example, â€œCheck out my companyâ€™s great new product.â€

sections.title: Our companyâ€™s policy says that employees shouldnâ€™t post positive reviews online about our products without clearly disclosing their relationship to the company. All of our employees agree to abide by this policy when theyâ€™re hired. But we have several thousand people working here and we canâ€™t monitor what they all do on their own computers and other devices when they arenâ€™t at work. Are we liable if an employee posts a review of one of our products, either on our company website, on a third-party review site, or on social media, and doesnâ€™t disclose that relationship?
sections.text:
It wouldnâ€™t be reasonable to expect you to monitor every social media posting by all of your employees. However, you should establish a formal program to remind employees periodically of your policy. Also, if you learn that employees have posted reviews on the companyâ€™s website or a social media site without adequately disclosing their relationship to the company, you should remind them of your company policy and ask them to remove those reviews or adequately disclose that theyâ€™re employees.
If, however, you actively encouraged your employees to write reviews of your products, you would be responsible for monitoring them (both in terms of disclosing that they are employees and for problematic claims) despite any difficulty in doing so.

sections.title: What about employees of an ad agency or public relations firm? Can my agency ask our employees to spread the buzz about our clientsâ€™ products?
sections.text:
First, an ad agency (or any company, for that matter) shouldnâ€™t ask employees to say anything that isnâ€™t true. No one should endorse a product they havenâ€™t used or say things they donâ€™t believe about a product â€“ and an employer certainly shouldnâ€™t encourage employees to engage in that conduct.
Moreover, employees of an ad agency or public relations firm have a connection to the advertiser, which should be disclosed in all social media posts. Agencies asking their employees to spread the word must instruct those employees about their responsibilities to clearly and conspicuously disclose their relationship to the product theyâ€™re endorsing â€“ for example, â€œMy employer is paid to promote [name of product],â€ or simply â€œAdvertisement,â€ or when space is an issue, â€œAdâ€ or â€œ#ad.â€ Also, the agency would be responsible for employees who didnâ€™t comply with those instructions (or who make unsubstantiated performance claims).

sections.title: My company is a large retailer that sells many brands of products that we get from various suppliers. Do my companyâ€™s employees really need to disclose that theyâ€™re employees when reviewing third-party brands on our website?
sections.text: Yes. Knowing that reviewers work for a retailer that sells the products being reviewed would likely affect the weight or credibility that readers give to the reviews on your website.

sections.title: My company XYZ wants to tell our employees what to disclose on social media. Is â€œ#employeeâ€ good enough?
sections.text: Consumers will likely not understand â€œ#employeeâ€ to mean that the person is an employee of your company. Consumers would be more likely to understand â€œI work for XYZâ€ or â€œ#XYZ_Employee.â€ Then again, if consumers donâ€™t associate your companyâ€™s name with the product or brand being endorsed, that disclosure might not work either. It would be much clearer to use the words â€œmy companyâ€™sâ€ or â€œmy employerâ€™sâ€ in the body of the message when describing the product they are endorsing. It's a lot easier to understand and harder to miss.

sections.title: We want to run ads featuring endorsements from consumers who achieved the best results with our companyâ€™s product. Can we do that?
sections.text:
Endorsements claiming specific results usually will be interpreted to mean that the endorserâ€™s experience reflects what others can also expect. Statements like â€œResults not typicalâ€ or â€œIndividual results may varyâ€ wonâ€™t change that interpretation. That leaves advertisers with two choices:
Have adequate proof to back up the claim that the results shown in the ad are typical, or
Clearly and conspicuously disclose the generally expected performance in the circumstances shown in the ad.

sections.title: How would this principle about endorsers who achieved exceptional results apply in a real ad?
sections.text:
The Guides include several examples with practical advice on this topic. One example is about an ad in which an endorser says, â€œI lost 50 pounds in 6 months with QRS Weight-Loss.â€ If consumers canâ€™t generally expect to get those results, the ad should say how much weight consumers can expect to lose in similar circumstances â€“ for example, â€œWomen who use QRS Weight-Loss for six months typically lose 15 pounds.â€
The Guides have another example in which an endorser simply says, â€œI lost 50 pounds with QRS Weight-Loss,â€ without any reference to time period. If users donâ€™t typically lose that much weight, the ad should disclose what results they do generally achieve â€“ for example, â€œWomen who use QRS Weight-Loss lose 15 pounds on average.â€

sections.title: Our company website includes endorsements from some of our more successful customers who used our product during the past few years and mentions the results they got. We canâ€™t figure out now what the â€œgenerally expected resultsâ€ were back then. What should we do? Do we have to remove those endorsements?
sections.text:
There are two issues here. First, according to the Guides, if your website says or implies that the endorser currently uses the product in question, you can use that endorsement only as long as you have good reason to believe the endorser does still use the product. If youâ€™re using endorsements that are a few years old, itâ€™s your obligation to make sure the claims still are accurate. If your product has changed, itâ€™s best to get new endorsements.
Second, if your product is the same as it was when the endorsements were given and the claims are still accurate, you probably can use the old endorsements if the disclosures are consistent with what the generally expected results are now.

Each year, the Ombudsman evaluates the conduct of these activities and rates each agencyâ€™s responsiveness to small businesses. Small businesses can comment to the Ombudsman without fear of reprisal. To comment, call toll-free 1-888-REGFAIR (1-888-734-3247) or go to www.sba.gov/ombudsman .
